answers.answer: Do you have recent labs to post so that we can see how they look?  If so, please post them and include reference ranges.The numbness you describe in your feet could be neuropathy, which can be caused by things other than diabetes.  One culprit is B-12 deficiency, so you might consider having that tested.  If you do, bear in mind that any result below about 500 is questionable.You might also do some research into Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome.  It's similar to Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, but in the ankle rather than the wrist.

question: I had my thyroid removed in 2006 because it had become enlarged and made swallowing difficult. Put on Levothyroxin 112 mcg and Calcitriol. Just this month doctor increased dosage to 125 mcg. Ever since my surgery I get cramps or Charlie horses, I don't really know how to describe it when I flex my arms. Is this a result of thyroid removal? If so, any thoughts on treatment. Am I missing a vitamin or mineral? Also, I don't know if this is related, because I had the nodules on my thyroid so many years before removal (probably 20+), but during that time I started having numbness in my toes, starting with the outside corners of my big toes. Now the entire outside of my big toes, my entire second toes and one side of each of my third toes are numb. My sugar levels are fine. Not quite sure what to make of this. Thank you.
title: muscle cramps & numb toes
